title: Absolute irreducibility
summary: In mathematics, a multivariate polynomial defined over the rational numbers is absolutely irreducible if it is  irreducible over the complex field.[1][2][3] For example, x 2 + y 2 − 1 {\displaystyle x^{2}+y^{2}-1} is absolutely irreducible, but while x 2 + y 2 {\displaystyle x^{2}+y^{2}} is irreducible over the integers and the reals, it is reducible over the complex numbers as x 2 + y 2 = ( x + i y ) ( x − i y ) , {\displaystyle x^{2}+y^{2}=(x+iy)(x-iy),} and thus not absolutely irreducible.
